description: This course will provide students with a theoretical foundation and a set of practical tools for the management of innovation, and the change associated with it, both in corporate settings and start-up situations. For the purposes of the course, innovation is defined as the profitable commercialization of a new idea: product, market, process or technology. The theoretical background will be provided by multiple readings, your knowledge of which will be tested in a readings report. The practical tools will be provided via lecture/discussion sessions, your skills at which will be demonstrated in an innovation plan for an actual innovation situation.
name: INNOV, CHG AND ENT

values.comments:
This course will provide students with a theoretical foundation and a set of practical tools for the management of innovation, and the change associated with it, both in corporate settings and start-up situations. For the purposes of the course, innovation is defined as the profitable commercialization of a new idea: product, market, process or technology. The theoretical background will be provided by multiple readings, the knowledge of which will be tested in a readings report. The practical tools will be provided via lecture/discussion sessions, the skills at which will be demonstrated in an innovation plan for an actual innovation situation.

	Students overall “enjoyed the class.” One student said they would “recommend this course to any and all Wharton students.” Many students enjoyed the readings and also like the professor’s humor. 

	Most students liked the Professor Macmillan and said he “demonstrated a profound expertise of the material.” One student did say, however, that it was “hard to understand the professor.”

	A few students commented that the group evaluation had too much weight. This is an upper level course in the management department.
